channel.title: Single Player RSC (offline)
channel.description:
Would anybody be interested in RSC single player (possibly iron-man, too?) that is completely playable without any sort of internet connection? If so I can make this and even port it to Android, and maybe iOS (using RoboVM)?
Discuss.

item.title: Single Player RSC (offline)
item.dc:creator: @RSC_Jerry_2001 RSC Jerry 2001
item.description:
@RSC_Jerry_2001 wrote:

Still in development, making a lot of progress.

Read full topic

item.title: Single Player RSC (offline)
item.dc:creator: @Dustin_Jr Dustin Jr
item.description:
@Dustin_Jr wrote:

[quote=“RSC Jerry 2001, post:11, topic:552050”][quote author=mft004 link=topic=670967.msg4487112#msg4487112 date=1434834318]
Well to be honest I don’t understand any of that

But as to the original question, sure I’d be very pleased to see a single player RSC. I’m currently working on one myself, but only in terms of getting the noobscape thing, reverting things to the 2001 look and using localhost. Never thought it would be so complicated, but I’m having fun trying to work things out

So yeh, all the best in your quest, Jerry!
[/quote]

Thanks for the support. I’ve started working on this project this morning. :)[/quote]

Update?

Read full topic

item.title: Single Player RSC (offline)
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“gawdz666, post:8, topic:552050”][quote author=-Nothing link=topic=670967.msg4487016#msg4487016 date=1434731220]

So you are going to port the client and server and run both on your android device?

Nope. The client’s action will be handled by the client itself. There will be no networking library or packets whatsoever.

So the client will load the objects handle all server sided actions inside the client. Well since this has to be multi threaded and may be a resource hog to a phone i say good luck and do it up.

It’s not that big of a resource hog if you do it properly. It’s going to use bit more storage space but that’s it.

If you don’t know how to do it properly then it might be an resource hog. For example load all objects, npcs, items etc at once instead of loading just the ones you need to sector that is loaded. You don’t need multiple threads either.

I disagree with this because you already have a single thread when the applet loads.

You would then have to keep all client actions within the applet thread and all saving and handling of the “server sided actions” in the same thread. I dunno i just disagree everything being on a single thread.

There are two threads in client, one thread used for connection processing and the main thread(you should stop calling it an applet thread btw) which handles everything from packet handling, game processing, and rendering.

The application would work just fine with single thread only, as the tasks which server does when it comes to playing the game are simple and you don’t need to process more than just the sectors that are being rendered, which is total of 4 sectors. That’s very little compared to what server has to do each tick.

You only use multiple threads when you want to handle multiple things at same time independently, or without slowing something down, which you don’t really need to do in this case. But for sake of cleaner code, it might be a good idea and it wouldn’t be a resource hog to do that, unlike you implied.
[/quote]

Oh so the applet doesnt have its own thread?

Quickly open up whatever rsc source you have check out whatever you call the applets java file(GameApplet.java usually).

Check in the init of the applet.

K[/quote]
Sure it does, but it doesn’t mean the correct way to call the thread is ‘applet thread’. Applet is merely a way to display the game, just like Frame.

Take another look at what the thread does, it has literally nothing to do with applet, therefore ‘applet thread’ is not the correct term.

public final void run() {
        getGameComponent().addKeyListener(this);
        getGameComponent().addMouseListener(this);
        getGameComponent().addMouseMotionListener(this);
        if(gameLoadingScreen == 1) {
            gameLoadingScreen = 2;
            graphics = getGraphics();
            loadLoadingScreen();
            drawLoadingScreen(0, "Loading...");
            loadGame();
            gameLoadingScreen = 0;
        }
        int i = 0;
        int k = 256;
        int sleepTime = 1;
        int j1 = 0;
        for(int k1 = 0; k1 < 10; k1++)
            timeArray[k1] = System.currentTimeMillis();

        while(runStatus >= 0)  {
            if(runStatus > 0) {
                runStatus--;
                if(runStatus == 0) {
                    closeProgram();
                    gameWindowThread = null;
                    return;
                }
            }
            int i2 = k;
            int j2 = sleepTime;
            k = 300;
            sleepTime = 1;
            long l1 = System.currentTimeMillis();
            if(timeArray[i] == 0L) {
                k = i2;
                sleepTime = j2;
            } else
            if(l1 > timeArray[i])
                k = (int)((long)(2560 * refreshRate) / (l1 - timeArray[i]));
            if(k < 25)
                k = 25;
            if(k > 256) {
                k = 256;
                sleepTime = (int)((long)refreshRate - (l1 - timeArray[i]) / 10L);
                if(sleepTime < gameMinThreadSleepTime)
                    sleepTime = gameMinThreadSleepTime;
            }
            try {
                Thread.sleep(sleepTime);
            }
            catch(InterruptedException _ex) { }
            timeArray[i] = l1;
            i = (i + 1) % 10;
            if(sleepTime > 1) {
                for(int k2 = 0; k2 < 10; k2++)
                    if(timeArray[k2] != 0L)
                        timeArray[k2] += sleepTime;

            }
            int l2 = 0;
            while(j1 < 256)  {
                checkInputs();
                j1 += k;
                if(++l2 > fie) {
                    j1 = 0;
                    fij += 6;
                    if(fij > 25) {
                        fij = 0;
                        keyF1Toggle = true;
                    }
                    break;
                }
            }
            fij--;
            j1 &= 0xff;
            drawWindow();
        }
        if(runStatus == -1)
            closeProgram();
        gameWindowThread = null;
    }

From: https://github.com/xetr0v/mpc-client/
That client is horribly named…yuck, no wonder you had the assumption that thread is solely for applet.

gawdz666:

Single thread is horrible. You need to save, have cleanups, handle interactions, handle loading of characters and data. But whatever im kinda done with this convo gl with this project if you do decide to do it.

As if those were something that would require another thread… Saving needs to be done upon logout, you clean sectors after loading new ones, loading of characters and data when you press ‘play’, interactions are simple and processing them is fast.

You seem to be stuck thinking of processing lots of players at once. You are only processing one on single player.

Read full topic

item.title: Single Player RSC (offline)
item.dc:creator: @gawdz666 gawdz666
item.description:
@gawdz666 wrote:

[quote="-Nothing, post:7, topic:552050"][quote author=gawdz666 link=topic=670967.msg4487011#msg4487011 date=1434728429]

So you are going to port the client and server and run both on your android device?

Nope. The client’s action will be handled by the client itself. There will be no networking library or packets whatsoever.

So the client will load the objects handle all server sided actions inside the client. Well since this has to be multi threaded and may be a resource hog to a phone i say good luck and do it up.

It’s not that big of a resource hog if you do it properly. It’s going to use bit more storage space but that’s it.

If you don’t know how to do it properly then it might be an resource hog. For example load all objects, npcs, items etc at once instead of loading just the ones you need to sector that is loaded. You don’t need multiple threads either.

I disagree with this because you already have a single thread when the applet loads.

You would then have to keep all client actions within the applet thread and all saving and handling of the “server sided actions” in the same thread. I dunno i just disagree everything being on a single thread.
[/quote]
There are two threads in client, one thread used for connection processing and the main thread(you should stop calling it an applet thread btw) which handles everything from packet handling, game processing, and rendering.

The application would work just fine with single thread only, as the tasks which server does when it comes to playing the game are simple and you don’t need to process more than just the sectors that are being rendered, which is total of 4 sectors. That’s very little compared to what server has to do each tick.

You only use multiple threads when you want to handle multiple things at same time independently, or without slowing something down, which you don’t really need to do in this case. But for sake of cleaner code, it might be a good idea and it wouldn’t be a resource hog to do that, unlike you implied.[/quote]

Oh so the applet doesnt have its own thread?

Quickly open up whatever rsc source you have check out whatever you call the applets java file(GameWindow.java or GameApplet.java usually).

Check in the init of the applet.

K.

Anyways there are a few threads you can kill but there is more you need to handle.

Single thread is horrible. You need to save, have cleanups, handle interactions, handle loading of characters and data. But whatever im kinda done with this convo gl with this project if you do decide to do it.

Read full topic

So you are going to port the client and server and run both on your android device?

Nope. The client’s action will be handled by the client itself. There will be no networking library or packets whatsoever.

So the client will load the objects handle all server sided actions inside the client. Well since this has to be multi threaded and may be a resource hog to a phone i say good luck and do it up.

It’s not that big of a resource hog if you do it properly. It’s going to use bit more storage space but that’s it.

If you don’t know how to do it properly then it might be an resource hog. For example load all objects, npcs, items etc at once instead of loading just the ones you need to sector that is loaded. You don’t need multiple threads either.
[/quote]

I disagree with this because you already have a single thread when the applet loads.

You would then have to keep all client actions within the applet thread and all saving and handling of the “server sided actions” in the same thread. I dunno i just disagree everything being on a single thread.[/quote]
There are two threads in client, one thread used for connection processing and the main thread(you should stop calling it an applet thread btw) which handles everything from packet handling, game processing, and rendering.

The application would work just fine with single thread only, as the tasks which server does when it comes to playing the game are simple and you don’t need to process more than just the sectors that are being rendered, which is total of 4 sectors. That’s very little compared to what server has to do each tick.

You only use multiple threads when you want to handle multiple things at same time independently, or without slowing something down, which you don’t really need to do in this case. But for sake of cleaner code, it might be a good idea and it wouldn’t be a resource hog to do that, unlike you implied.
